headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to today's Colgate-Palmolive Company Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded and is being simulcast live at www.colgatepalmolive.com.Today's conference call will include forward-looki
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to today's Colgate-Palmolive Company Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded and is being simulcast live at www.colgatepalmolive.com.
Today's conference call will include forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from these statements. Please refer to the earnings press release and the most recent Form 10-K and subsequent SEC filings, all available on Colgate's website, for a discussion of the factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from these statements.
This conference call will also include a discussion of non-GAAP financial measures, including those identified in Tables 8 and 9 of the earnings press release. A full reconciliation with the corresponding GAAP measures is included in the earnings press release and is available on Colgate's website.
Now for opening remarks, I would like to turn the call over to the Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, Bina Thompson. Please go ahead, Bina.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Angela, and good morning and welcome to our second quarter earnings release conference call. With me this morning are Ian Cook, Chairman, President and CEO; Dennis Hickey, CFO; Victoria Dolan, Corporate Controller; and Elaine Paik, Treasurer.
componenttext:
Thank you, Angela, and good morning and welcome to our second quarter earnings release conference call. With me this morning are Ian Cook, Chairman, President and CEO; Dennis Hickey, CFO; Victoria Dolan, Corporate Controller; and Elaine Paik, Treasurer. 
Happily, the momentum we saw in the first quarter continued into the second quarter with good organic sales growth within our targeted range of 4% to 7% and as compared to the strong quarter of last year. Gross profit margin accelerated nicely, which allowed us to increase worldwide advertising as a percent of sales. 
And as you will year in more detail, our market share is our strong. New products continue to play important role in our strategy. Innovation across categories have helped fuel growth around the world And our Global Growth and Efficiency Program is on track. Our balance sheet is wrong and the so is our cash generation. 
We continue to be faced with macroeconomic challenges in many parts of the world, coupled with ongoing and sometimes volatile currency headwinds. So in light of this, we're particularly pleased with the results. 
Just a quick housekeeping note before we get into the divisions. As was mentioned in this morning's 8-K filing, as a result of management changes effective April 1, 2016, the company realigned the geographic structure of its Europe, South Pacific and Asia operating segment. Beginning this quarter, the results of the South Pacific operations are reported in the Asia Pacific operating segment. There's no impact on historical company results overall. For informational purposes, historical geographic segments and geographic sales growth information conforming to the new reporting structure has been provided within this morning's 8-K and the For Investors section of Colgate's website at www.colgatepalmolive.com.
So now let's turn to the divisions. Starting with North America. We're pleased with another solid quarter in North America. Our U.S. and Canada businesses, including our Thompson main and professional businesses, contributed to good growth. Innovation across categories helped drive market shares. And as referenced in the press release, market shares increased on a year-to-date basis in toothpaste, manual toothbrushes, mouthwash, liquid hand soap, body wash, liquid cleaners and fabric conditioners. 
Our oral care franchises are strong. In toothpaste, our leadership position year-to-date through June of 35.7% has increased to 35.8% in latest read. New products supported by impactful marketing campaigns and in-store activity had been critical to this success. Colgate Total Daily Repair toothpaste, our most recent addition to the Colgate Total equity, is driving growth in the superpremium segment with year-to-date sales increasing from 3.7% in 2015 to 4.3% in 2016, increasing our overall Colgate Total share by 60 basis points.
In addition to equity driver, such as engaging media and in-store and online support in the second quarter, we link to Colgate Total to National Women's health week. Colgate Optic White is performing well with a full portfolio, including multiple toothpaste offerings, as well as whitening toothbrushes and mouthwash for a complete regimen approach. Adding to the basic Optic White, Optic White Platinum Express White and Optic White Platinum Lasting White variance was the recent launch of Optic White Platinum High Impact White toothpaste. Our overall Optic White toothpaste share is at 6.3% year-to-date and in the second quarter, reached 6.6%, up 80 basis points from the year-ago period.
Colgate 360 toothbrush continues to deliver differentiated and incremental innovation. In the first quarter, we launched Colgate 360 degree in our health whitening toothbrush with Spira polishing bristles and stay in racing cap. Market share for the Colgate 360-degree toothbrush ratios growth from 13.1% in 2011 to 19.8% in 2015 and is up again this year, achieving 22.1% through June.
Continuing the momentum for the Colgate 360 franchise, shipping this month in the U.S. is the new Colgate 360 Total Advance 4 Zone Manual toothbrush. This revolutionary new toothbrush feature the high tech ergonomic design and a tongue-in-cheek cleaner with longer rubber knobs than any previous Colgate 360 toothbrush. It's specifically designed to great the 4 zones of your math, your teeth, tongue, cheeks and gums. This launch is being supported via comprehensive activation in key retailers. 
And in Personal Care, innovation in both liquid hand soap and body wash have driven share increases. In the first quarter, we launched so soft killer foaming hand soap. The simple general formula cleans and purifies and has 100% natural fragrance with no Dyer alcohol. And we told you last quarter about So Soft Luminous oil body wash, which comes in 2 variants, avocado oil and iris, and macadamia oil and BNE. This new line has been incremental to our overall body wash share, and the macadamia oil and BNE there and has been the #1 soft body wash parent at a major U.S. retailer for 13 out of the last 15 weeks. Let's turn to Europe.
Despite continued macroeconomic uncertainties across the region, Europe delivered another quarter of positive organic sales growth. Toothpaste market shares remained relatively stable at 35.2% across the region. And we enjoyed market share increases in manual and battery toothbrushes, body wash, bar soap and fabric conditioners.
While toothpaste share was relatively stable across the region, we saw some good increases in individual countries, as referenced in the press release, with strength in both the Colgate and Gaba brands. And you may recall, we told you last quarter about the rollout of our toothbrush plus whitening pen, which has met with great success. Original overall manual toothbrush share is at 27% year-to-date, up 250 basis points from the year-ago period and over 10 share points ahead of the nearest competitor. 
In France, one of the first launch markets to launch the toothbrush plus whitening pen, our overall year-to-date toothbrush share has gone to 25.5% from 18.2% in the year-ago period. Our year-to-date body wash shares is up 40 basis points from 12.7% to 13.1% with the gains coming from both the Palmolive and Sanex brands. You recall we recently launched a range of Sanex products, including body wash for dry and atopic skin. And in the bigger Sanex markets, France, Spain and the U.K, our overall body wash shares increased 100 basis points, 140 basis points and 30 basis points, respectively, year-to-date. 
Our fabric conditioner share year-to-date increased 150 basis points across the region from 23.3% to 24.8%. And our largest market, France, saw growth of over 1 point from 47.4% to 48.5% with the most recently lead at 50.1% and this in the face of continued discompetitive activity.
More innovation is found to the back half of this year. And in other parts of the but the toothpaste whitening segment is strong and growing at almost twice the rate of the overall toothpaste category. We lead in this segment with a 43% year-to-date share. So to capitalize on the growth opportunity, we are relaunching Colgate Max White Optix with a revitalized graphics and improved formula, which is 3x more powerful for instantly and visibly whiter teeth. 
A new Gaba product is there a peridont expert, a clinically proven daily use toothpaste which increases gum resistance periodontitis. This offering seals the gap in our portfolio. 
And in Personal Care, we hope to continue the momentum with the body wash with the launch of Palmolive Gourmet Spa, a unique concept, which has been proven in geographies. As I'm sure you recall, this range of body wash has a high density, creamy formula offered in vanilla pleasure, chocolate passion, peach delight and strawberry touch. New sweet packaging provides a premium look, high-quality satin finishing, extended communication surface and strong shelf impact. 
Sanex is now launching Sanex Men, a unique positioning for the mass market, as it is the first range of products, body washes, shampoo and underarm protection, which is truly focused on men's health, skin health. 
Turning then to Latin America. The strong organic sales growth of the first quarter continued into the second quarter. And as you would expect, innovation contributed to these results across categories. In toothpaste, our regional share year-to-date is up 80 basis points to a record 75.5%. In Brazil, our share is at a record 73.3% with the most recent lead at 73.5%. 
In the highly competitive whitening category, our Colgate Luminous White equity is doing well. The complete regimen offering of toothpaste, manual toothbrush, toothbrush plus whitening pen and mouthwash had been supported by a new and strong working campaign designed to make you shine.
In Mexico, where our overall toothpaste share is back over 80%, Colgate Luminous White toothpaste has achieved a record 9.1% share year-to-date, up 60 basis points over the year-ago period. Our regional mouthwash share is also strong, up 30 basis points to 31.5% year-to-date. 
In Brazil, the launch of Colgate Plax Ice Infinity has met with exceptional results and driven our share of 170 basis points year-to-date to 35.2%. In the Personal Care category, in Brazil, we launched Protex pro Trotter with macadamia oil, a line of bar soap, body wash and liquid hand soap offering moisturizing sensation, as well as the antibacterial protection for which Protex is known. 
The bundle is incremental to the Protex equity, driving the Protex body cleansing share from 13.6% in December of 2015 to 14.6% in the most recent period, further establishing Protex as a leading antibacterial body cleansing equity in Brazil. 
Our new product flow is continuing in the second half of the year. Launching now our 2 new toothpaste, the first, price and premium range as a category, Colgate Total Professional Daily Repair, creates the shield in 100% of the mouth surfaces that helps repair early enamel demineralization and prevents teeth and gum problem. The second, Colgate Triple Action Extra Whitening, should help drive share in the base business. Its exclusive formula with micro-polishing particles provides extra widening. It removes stains, works from the first brushing and restores the teeth's natural whiteness. 
Along with the triple action toothpaste will be a companion Colgate Triple Action whitening toothbrush. To further build on our momentum with Protex, we are continuing the launch of Protex For Men 3 on 1. The product, which comes in liquid or bar soap form, delivers 3 benefits. Besides eliminating 9.9% of bacteria, it actively cleans the body without drying out the skin. It prepares the skin for soft shade and it can be use as a shampoo, leading men's hair clean with a masculine fragrance. 
Turning then to Asia South Pacific. Results was somewhat muted in the region in this quarter on an overall basis with pockets of strengths. For instance, in the Philippines, our toothpaste share increased over 200 basis points year-to-date to 62.6% with the most recent lead at 64.6%. Lower price offering, such as Colgate Triple Action and Colgate Fresh Confidence, as well as premium priced Colgate Sensitive, contributed to the share gains. And to continue the momentum, we are in the process we're introducing Colgate Fresh Confidence Bamboo Charcoal Toothpaste in that market. 
In India, our manual toothbrush share is up 200 basis points year-to-date to 45.7%. Colgate Zig Zag Black has contributed to the share gain. And as you would expect, we have more innovation slated for the balance of the year. In India, the consumer believes strongly in natural ingredients. And we told you last quarter about 2 toothpaste initiatives: Colgate Active Salt with means and Colgate sensitive with global essence. 
A third toothpaste launched in this order under to Bakos sub brand is Colgate call quite a whole. The positioning is a toothpaste packed with the goodness of natural ingredients help keep dental problems away. In the toothbrush category, we are launching Colgate Slim Soft Charcoal Spiral. Charcoal toothbrushes have been particularly successful in this region, and this latest brush offers spiral bristles with charcoal.
Now flush is strong but growing category across the region. Our regional shares up year-to-date by 30 basis points to a record 28%. And to continue the momentum this quarter in India, we are launching Colgate Plax spicy fresh, delivering spicy freshness without the burn. 
Turning then to Africa/Eurasia. Our business across the region remains solid despite macroeconomic challenges and continued currency headwinds. Our toothpaste market share is strong. 
In Russia, our share is up 120 basis points year-to-date to 34.9%. Much of the growth has come from our mainstream businesses: Colgate Triple Action and Colgate Maximum Cavity Protection. In Turkey, our share is around the prior year-to-date level at 26.8%. But in the most recent period, our share is at 28.1%. And in South Africa, our year-to-date share is at 50.4%, up 10 basis points with the most recently at 50.6%.
In South Africa, our manual toothbrush share is up 60 basis points to 38.6% year-to-date with the most recent lead at 39.2%. Now we've told you before about Colgate Total Pro Breath Health toothpaste for its launch in Latin America. This toothpaste with a new formula with ON 12 complex that neutralizes bad breath bacteria while protecting 100% of the surfaces of the mouth, will be rolled out across of these regions supported by media and key visuals in store to communicate the benefits. 
Similarly from other regions, we will launching Colgate Sensitive Pro-Relief repair and prevent toothpaste, formulated to repair the cause of sensitivity and prevent further sensitivities from gum recession. A product developed for the Russian market is our new Colgate ulti-herb ginseng, which adds ginseng, a natural healing ingredient, to the Colgate ulti herbs toothpaste launch previously. 
In the Personal Care category, we are relaunching our Palmolive Gourmet Spa line and shower gels with improved graphics. And in addition, we've added 2 new variants, mint and coconut.
Turning to health. As with the Colgate businesses, health continues with solid results fueled by successful innovation. Launched now over 1 year ago, Prescription Diet Metabolic Plus continues to deliver outstanding performance. The complete range of dry instills has been rapidly distributed across all regions and is now selling in 46 countries. Building on this solid metabolic plus platform, in May of this year, we launched Prescription Diet Metabolic Plus urinary stress for cats, with clinically proven nutrition for concurrent conditions of obesity and feline urinary tract disease. This launch was integrated into an overall focus on urinary problems, which are very common in cats. The product is now available in 13 countries across the North America and Europe.
Dermatological disorders and skin issues represent the fourth largest therapeutic food category in dollar sales for pets. In 2016, we have 2 major initiatives in this area: Prescription Diet Dem defense and an upgrade of our Prescription Diet CD. 
Prescription Diet Dem defense is held first and only nutrition with 60 [ph] guard complex, formulated to reduce signs of environmental allergy by disrupting the internal allergy response and creating a barrier against future episodes in dogs. Now in the U.S. and Europe and would be rolled out across the rest of the world. The science was presented both at a global dorm symposium in April in California and at the World Congress Veterinary Dermatology in May in France, driving awareness of our key thought leaders. 
Our prescription diet CD upgrade has been reformulated to increase ingredients known to support skin and coat NGI health. And in addition, we launched a small bites variance for the rapidly growing small dog population. Innovations across our science diet platform continues to do well. 
In addition to our Science Diet footprint and Science Diet healthy cuisine, which we told you about last quarter, our Science Diet urinary hairball control for cats is exceeding original sales estimates in North America. It's now the #1 wet variant for Science Diet. 
In Europe, we have an online quiz and game, as well as videos for the products to generate interest and trial. 
So in summary then, we're pleased with how the year is progressing. Our organic sales growth is solid and our savings program, as well as our Global Growth and Efficiency Program, are delivering a healthy growth profit for its margin increase. Around the world, Colgate people are executing our focus strategy. Our innovation and pipeline is full, and we're excited about what is yet to come. So we look forward to sharing our results with you as we go through the balance of the year. And now, Angela, I should like to turn it over to questions.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Wendy Nicholson with Citi Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Wendy Nicholson with Citi Research.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think I heard, Bina, you comment on China, even though in the press release, you mentioned volume declines. So could you talk about the magnitude of the volume declines in China? What the pricing environment was like? And maybe a broader question
componenttext: I don't think I heard, Bina, you comment on China, even though in the press release, you mentioned volume declines. So could you talk about the magnitude of the volume declines in China? What the pricing environment was like? And maybe a broader question of kind of what's going on? Is it your market share? I know proctors has talked about the need to more premium the world care category. Could you share that view so sort of specific of the quarter, how the China affair and bigger picture what's your take in China right now?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question, Wendy. I guess, overall, I would start a little bit further back and say that in balancing all of the geographies and the headwinds we are facing in the world, we were delighted to post an overall 4.5% organic growth. Asia, as you
componenttext:
Thanks for the question, Wendy. I guess, overall, I would start a little bit further back and say that in balancing all of the geographies and the headwinds we are facing in the world, we were delighted to post an overall 4.5% organic growth. Asia, as you saw, was more muted at 2%, although with some highlights, as Bina has already discussed. I don't think based on what you have heard over the last couple of weeks from other companies that operate in China that there are some short-term issues in that geography. So let me explain our analysis of what's going on, which we view as a relatively short-term issue, as I will describe. And then I can come back and talk about our market shares, both overall and respective to China. So first of all, in terms of what's going on in the marketplace. 2 things, Number one, as we entered the second quarter, the consumer consumption slowed quite sharply. It picked back up. And as we look forward, we think that the consumer consumption in China for the balance of the year will continue to be around mid single-digits. But there was a slowdown entering the second quarter. That was compounded by a fairly large structural change that's going on in China, which is the shift of business from brick-and-mortar to online. Online showing very sharp growth. Indeed, our online business doubled year-to-date in China. And both of those things saw inventory build with the wholesalers, in part, because of backdoor selling from the brick-and-mortar retailers, which distorted pricing in the market and build inventory with wholesalers. Now we have seen in that before as you know, and we are seeing it again. And we are in the process of dealing with that inventory situation. And we think, as it was the last time, it will be fully corrected by the time we get to the fourth quarter of the this year. But it will continue for a little while.
In terms of market share, we talked on the last call about market share in China. I would comment first on the world. And I would say on the world that our market share, in dollar terms, which is what we comment on in the press release, is modestly down, but that is also due with foreign exchange mix. In fact, our market share, on a constant currency basis, is up. And our market share in volume terms is up around the world. In China, our market share is beginning to recover in the second quarter, showing 2 periods of uptrend as the innovation that we spoke about last time, which is premium innovation, to your point, Wendy, is beginning to take hold in the marketplace.
So we don't think we're in balance from a portfolio point of view. The primary local competitor that we spoke about, you to buy all has been flat in market share terms for the past 6 periods. And we think our innovation flow is good. So for our business, based on the analysis we seem, it is in this temporal adjustment again of a slowdown in consumption, which is picked backup but perhaps, more substantial ship overtime move from brick-and-mortar to e-commerce. Again, if they consumption is mid single-digits, we will simply grow our business where consumers do their shopping, the consumption levels will not change. So something to work through, but we don't think substantive and we certainly don't think that we have a portfolio issue as we go forward.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I know you commented in the past that you're kind of agnostic at least in developed markets about selling to brick-and-mortar versus online retailers. Does that apply as well to China? Or is there a margin difference between where you're selling?
componenttext: And I know you commented in the past that you're kind of agnostic at least in developed markets about selling to brick-and-mortar versus online retailers. Does that apply as well to China? Or is there a margin difference between where you're selling?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're agnostic.
componenttext: We're agnostic.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will now go to Ali Dibadj with Bernstein.
componenttext: We will now go to Ali Dibadj with Bernstein.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to drove a little bit into Latin America. And so, look it's more than half of your emerging market business right now. So at about kind of 9.5% pricing that you took from that region, that's driving about 80%-ish, 3 quarter [ph] of 80%-ish of your
componenttext: I want to drove a little bit into Latin America. And so, look it's more than half of your emerging market business right now. So at about kind of 9.5% pricing that you took from that region, that's driving about 80%-ish, 3 quarter [ph] of 80%-ish of your emerging market, 6.5% growth you mentioned in the release. And to be clear, you're not unique in that reliance among the companies that you cover. But I wanted to get a sense of the sustainability you see in that, especially as we saw some of your Brazil volumes get a little bit worse lately sequentially here. We see that Latin America is the only region, at least from your orr that you increase at spend on. Mexico is less out of share gaining kind of the list of countries, Mexico left that to Latin America. So I wanted to get a sense of you about the sustainability of driving so much of your growth from that region.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we're quite optimistic on Latin America, which maybe a contrarian thing to say, largely based on the relationship we have with the consumers that buy our products. Now the Mexican market share is still north of 80, which is a very respectable p
componenttext: Yes. Well, we're quite optimistic on Latin America, which maybe a contrarian thing to say, largely based on the relationship we have with the consumers that buy our products. Now the Mexican market share is still north of 80, which is a very respectable place to be. And we quoted the Brazilian share now approaching 74%. I actually wouldn't use the term relying on pricing in Latin America. I would more say that the pricing -- that we have the elasticity to take the pricing with our consumer in order to offset the translation impacts on costs driven by weakening foreign exchange. You know well from our history that while we see volume slow down as the pricing goes through, that, that comes back over time. And our forward thinking on Latin America is that the volume negative will dissipate across the back half of the year. And the important thing for us is to watch our market shares. And as I said earlier, our market share is not only up country by country, but they're up on a volume basis as well. So people are staying with our product. If we don't face the headwind in costs, as we said coming into this year, you would see our forward business momentum be more volume driven than pricing driven. And indeed, we still stand behind the comment that for this year, as we deliver within in the 4 to 7 range that we are staying with, it will be more volume driven than pricing driven for the entire year. So it is a response to the headwinds that we face to help generate the kind of gross margin expansion that you are seeing, which allows us to continue to lift our traditional advertising, which I know you favor, and at the same time, continue with the install work that we also believe engages with consumers. So we're very comfortable with our approach. And that comfort is based entirely on the enduring relationship we have with the consumers that by our products in that part of the world.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is up on the enduring relationship with consumers in that part of the world, it seems like you want to increase that through incremental advertising spend there, but nowhere else. So none of the other regions, you say, has been goes up as far as
componenttext: And this is up on the enduring relationship with consumers in that part of the world, it seems like you want to increase that through incremental advertising spend there, but nowhere else. So none of the other regions, you say, has been goes up as far as I could tell except for that region. So trying to get a better sense of that. And if you might be able to just give a little more granularity on Brazil. So are people trading down? What you see happening now? We've heard some people say it's bottoming. Just some perspective there.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, okay, as usual, thanks for the one question. The -- on Brazil, I think we take the view, as many others had announced, that we see this continuing for the balance of the year. We have not seen trading down in terms of our portfolio. They did, we did
componenttext: Well, okay, as usual, thanks for the one question. The -- on Brazil, I think we take the view, as many others had announced, that we see this continuing for the balance of the year. We have not seen trading down in terms of our portfolio. They did, we did not see that you will remember during the subprime period, and if consumers find themselves cash stretch, they tend to buy us more sites before they come back to the payday we can. So I would venture to say more continued turbulence in Brazil for the balance of the year. We have long said that we did not think this would be a short fix. Again, our category growth rates continue in that mid single-digit range. Yes, largely driven by pricing at this time. But these foreign exchange trends will eventually change. So that would be Brazil. And in terms of the advertising, Ali, I think you have to watch our planning over a year rather than drill into one geography and one quarter. We stand by what we say, which is that we are planning for our advertising for the full year to be up both absolutely and as a percentage to sales, and we will see how that unfolds over the balance of the year. Frankly, again, even though this may continue to be contrarian in some parts of the world where the consumers are particularly stressed, we are finding that the in-store efforts produce a better result with good brand scores a good ROI. And we will continue to do that if that -- in a balanced way, to build our brands.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now go to Olivia Tong with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll now go to Olivia Tong with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just for clarification. Is your share online in key markets similar to what we can see in brick-and-mortars? Or are there other -- are there markets where there are disconnects? And then just in terms of price mix following upon that. The price versus vol
componenttext: Just for clarification. Is your share online in key markets similar to what we can see in brick-and-mortars? Or are there other -- are there markets where there are disconnects? And then just in terms of price mix following upon that. The price versus volume contribution, obviously, going back to price being a bigger contributor versus volume. So first, does mix have any impact in there? And then just sort of your thoughts in the second half in terms of the dynamic. I know volume are bigger piece than price overtime, but just sort of clarification on that second half expectation.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the online is interesting. Because what you see online often is that the share composition is very different. So for example, in the U.S., we are the brand share leader online. But for example, our Thompson Maine business has a disproportionately ele
componenttext: Yes, the online is interesting. Because what you see online often is that the share composition is very different. So for example, in the U.S., we are the brand share leader online. But for example, our Thompson Maine business has a disproportionately elevated share online, which may trace to the demographics of the consumers. So you see our shares profiling strongly, but sometimes, the composition of those shares is very, very different to what you would see in the brick and mortar account. Relative to this pricing notion, I mean, our price was greater than our volume in this -- the second quarter for the reasons that I have mentioned. You will remember, our volume is a dollar weighted volume. So mix is not a factor in the discussion. And to repeat what we said to Ali, it is our planning. But for this year, in total, our growth, which will be within the 4 to 7 range, we have been guiding will be more driven towards volume than price on a relative basis to last year.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could follow up on default pricing. It's been pretty negative in developed markets, and in the case of the U.S. got more negative versus last year. And your main competitor seems to have a bit more of a sense of urgency in other categories. So what a
componenttext: If I could follow up on default pricing. It's been pretty negative in developed markets, and in the case of the U.S. got more negative versus last year. And your main competitor seems to have a bit more of a sense of urgency in other categories. So what are you seeing on the competitive front that's causing you to keep promotional levels heightened like this?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure the pricing situation in Europe is unique to us. If you talk about North America, often times, this traces here to the couponing that you use to put behind your new innovations. So we all have our faults and plans in terms of innovation
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure the pricing situation in Europe is unique to us. If you talk about North America, often times, this traces here to the couponing that you use to put behind your new innovations. So we all have our faults and plans in terms of innovation flows, which vary by company. But our pricing in North America, we think, overall, we get a good organic growth out of it. So it really does trade smaller to the innovation flow and the couponing that builds trial behind that innovation flow.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ian, just kind of a simple question. On share repurchase, just looking back, your share count, average share count, went down sequentially every quarter from 2006 and until 2015, yet it's gone actually up for the first time, both in 1Q and 2Q. So is there
componenttext: Ian, just kind of a simple question. On share repurchase, just looking back, your share count, average share count, went down sequentially every quarter from 2006 and until 2015, yet it's gone actually up for the first time, both in 1Q and 2Q. So is there a change in kind of thought of use of cash or share repurchase? Or is it just more of a short-term event?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We simply -- no, there is not a change. We simply got behind our results. So the -- for the year, we are still talking about a gross buyback of $1.2 billion to $1.3 billion. We fell behind, frankly, in the second quarter, which is the net result of what y
componenttext: We simply -- no, there is not a change. We simply got behind our results. So the -- for the year, we are still talking about a gross buyback of $1.2 billion to $1.3 billion. We fell behind, frankly, in the second quarter, which is the net result of what you see. Therefore, what you're going to see over the balance of the year is that share repurchase pick up. And on a gross basis, it's going to be between 300 and 400 a quarter, so that we realize the $1.2 billion, $1.3 billion range for the full year. So we're still holding to the full year. And therefore, there will be an uptick in the second half of the year to compensate.

componenttext: Okay. And that's reflected, I guess, in the share count on the outlook?

componenttextpreview: Is it John or Jonathan?
componenttext: Is it John or Jonathan?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Jonathan. When you think about pricing and volume, particularly in Latin American, where you have such strong market shares. Is anything -- it starts me as kind of under companied like yourself space of that adjusted the time when you consumers are d
componenttext: It's Jonathan. When you think about pricing and volume, particularly in Latin American, where you have such strong market shares. Is anything -- it starts me as kind of under companied like yourself space of that adjusted the time when you consumers are dealing some distress in other areas from the currency movement, you're asking them to pay more for the products. When we -- assuming the currency, a more neutral currency situation in the future, how much pricing opportunity -- or the pricing that's happening today is increased value add, increased value you're bringing to the consumer, and how much do you think that last into a more neutral currency environment? Should we ever experience one again, hopefully at some point in the next year or two?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Jonathan. The -- Latin America is an interesting part of the world. The shopping consumer in Latin America is perhaps one of the most educated on the planet in terms of the vagaries of foreign exchange and what that means for a shopping baske
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Jonathan. The -- Latin America is an interesting part of the world. The shopping consumer in Latin America is perhaps one of the most educated on the planet in terms of the vagaries of foreign exchange and what that means for a shopping basket. So -- and the steps that we take are entirely driven by the currency. And if you talk qualitatively with consumers in Brazil, for example, they can almost tell you what the price of the group that they buy are going to be based on the foreign exchange move. I guess the good way to think about it is that our kinds of products, yes you're talking taking pricing, but you're talking taking pricing on an everyday product and at relatively modest levels on top of that. So it does not affect their loyalty to the brand over time, they have opportunities in terms of the different sizes. We have to buy at different price points and therefore, mitigate the cost impact from a cash outlay point of view, which indeed they do, do. But interestingly, they don't even trade down within our portfolio. So if they're buying the premium end of the Colgate portfolio, they keep buying that. They don't trade down to perhaps, what might -- you might say is a more economical option within our portfolio. So our kinds of products at the time these economies are going through what they are going through become the affordable luxuries that people continue to put in their shopping basket. So that's the way I would answer it, John.

componenttext: Going back a little bit about gross margin. I think maybe you were a little disappointed that no one asked you about it yet given gross margins were up 190 basis point. headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I was going to ask you to repeat the question because I like hearing 1 90. The -- so if we just do the traditional roll forward. The prior-year gross profit was 58.3. We got the benefit 110 basis points of the pricing. We had between funding the grow
componenttext: Yes, I was going to ask you to repeat the question because I like hearing 1 90. The -- so if we just do the traditional roll forward. The prior-year gross profit was 58.3. We got the benefit 110 basis points of the pricing. We had between funding the growth and restructuring, restructuring modest in gross profit, as you know, 190 basis points favorable. Material prices were a headwind of 110 basis points, nothing in leather. And I guess, 60.2, which is the 190 basis points. Now as we think about that for the balance of the year, I mean, first pleasingly, although these pleasing moments are quickly behind you. But pleasingly, this is the second back-to-back quarter now we've been above 60 in gross margin, which as you know, was a company goal. Indeed, the second edge slightly up on the first. But if you look at our gross profit for the first half of the year, it's up 150 basis points, 1.5 points. So as we, as you think about the balance of the year, I guess what we would say is our expectation is that our gross margin increase for the second half of the year will be around the same level as the first half, maybe even a little bit higher. And to the primary driver of that of course, is transaction headwinds will start to lessen as of the foreign exchange comparisons are on other event in now will improve year upon year.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about soap. So in the press release, innovation is called out seems to be largely driven by prescription Science Diet. I didn't see you mentioned Natural or Ideal Balance categories, brand. So I guess, curious if you could comment on why t
componenttext: I wanted to ask about soap. So in the press release, innovation is called out seems to be largely driven by prescription Science Diet. I didn't see you mentioned Natural or Ideal Balance categories, brand. So I guess, curious if you could comment on why the focus seems to be on the nutrition science, not natural, as I guess it has been more so in recent years. But if there's anything we should read into it from a consumer preference standpoint in terms of changing pace out there.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. I mean, I think whatever we do on Hill's, whatever we have done on Hill's, we are always extremely focus as a matter of strategy on the nutrition the diet provide. doesn't matter whether it's a prescription product, a science product or
componenttext: I don't think so. I mean, I think whatever we do on Hill's, whatever we have done on Hill's, we are always extremely focus as a matter of strategy on the nutrition the diet provide. doesn't matter whether it's a prescription product, a science product or even our Ideal Balance product. I think the thing you might want to read into it is that after we introduced Ideal Balance, we have been through an extensive process of changing the formula composition of our Science Diet product just the one not recommended or prescribed by a vet to change the composition of the ingredients in those products, to lead with protein and other ingredients that buyers of natural products value thereby no longer providing them with a reason to walk away from the nutrition of Science Diet because Science Diet doesn't offer them a formula composition of that they're looking for. That was a significant change that we made to make that piece of the business less vulnerable to a natural pure play. So Ideal Balance is doing okay. But I would say our major shift has been to make sure, from a dietary composition point of view, that our core Science Diet business is competitive. And of course, in making that change, have validated the fact that the nutritional benefit that the paired has provided is completely and change in making that formula adjustment. So I guess that's the way I would think about it. And all of the innovation that are being talked about on the Prescription Diet side, seems seen with the way to products, we translate that science, if you will, across Science Diet and even bring it to Ideal Balance, although we would market it in different ways, given the different positionings of each of those 3 segments of the business.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry in advance for the technical question. But just as I'm asking you about how you define things in your reporting, if I think about Europe, where you see pricing down again 3% this quarter, which I understand is a well documented trend. If I go back t
componenttext: Sorry in advance for the technical question. But just as I'm asking you about how you define things in your reporting, if I think about Europe, where you see pricing down again 3% this quarter, which I understand is a well documented trend. If I go back to 2009 and just index report really to 100, multiply it through the reported pricing, right. It implies that your pricing, your portfolio is down almost 20% in aggregate since that time. And obviously, there's been a big continuous mix component, I'm assuming, as you roll in new premium innovation that's helped offset that in the volume line. But as I think about how that flows through the margins, I'm assuming that, that premieralization has been beneficial to margins. But if I look at how you define the buckets of margin drivers, special by segment, you typically call out spanning the growth then all in it's kind of raw and packaging costs and then pricing. I just want to understand, maybe using Europe as an example, when there's a significant mix benefits or impact on margins, where does that fall? Is that netting against pricing, that mix benefit? Or is it somehow contributing to funding the growth as it relates to your margin drivers?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Well, thank you for the simple question. I think the mix benefit clearly has picked up in gross margin. And I would say it would be between pricing and cost in the gross margin calculation, based cost.
